column2: Mo. — Senator Claire McCaskill isn’t subtle in reminding voters what her campaign is all about. She’s rechristened it the “Your Health Care

column4: Ms. McCaskill and vulnerable Senate Democrats in Florida

She lambasted him for participating in a lawsuit that challenges the constitutionality of the Affordable Care Act and would end its protections for those with pre-existing conditions. He said he supported a program that would protect patients with high medical costs outside the current health care law. On the same day

column47: is leaning toward Mr. Hawley. “He said

column106: who also works in public relations

As a result
column2: a growing number of reproductive rights activists say it is time American women learn the facts about "self-managing abortion" with pills. Kate could tell something was wrong. She'd been feeling nauseous for days and her body just felt different. The 27-year-old massage school student and her boyfriend were supposed to leave on a short road trip together
column3: but before they hit the highway
column4: she asked him to drive to a local drugstore. Kate
column5: which is not her real name
column6: bought a pregnancy test and took it in the store bathroom. It was positive. "I probably lost all my colour
column7: she recalls. I was pretty devastated." Over the six-hour drive that followed
column8: the young couple wrestled with the decision in front of them - to become parents or not. Kate was open to the idea
column9: but as a full-time student doing odd jobs on the side to make ends meet
column10: she was also broke. Her boyfriend told her he wasn't ready to become a father. "I struggle putting food on the table and I'm in debt
column11: she says. I just didn't see how I could justify putting a kid in that situation." The nearest abortion clinic was hours away
column12: and the attendant who answered the phone told her that because she was less than 10 weeks along
column13: she could terminate the pregnancy with pills - one dose of the drug mifepristone to take at the clinic
column16: to take at home. She was also told it would cost nearly $800. Kate was shocked. "It would have taken everything I have. I don't know how I would have paid rent." So she did what thousands of women around the globe do every year - she decided to try to have an abortion on her own. Despite the fact that abortion is legal in the US
column17: various studies have estimated that hundreds of thousands of Americans have tried to end a pregnancy without the help of a doctor at some point in their lives
column22: drugs or self-harm. Although accurate figures are difficult to come by
column23: one study estimated that in the state of Texas alone
column26: 000 people had attempted a self-induced abortion. A New York Times analysis of Google data found that in 2015
column28: 000 searches from the US for information about self-managed abortion - phrases like "how to have a miscarriage
column29: how to self-abort" and "buy abortion pills online". With the confirmation of Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the US Supreme Court
column30: pro-choice activists are preparing for the possible dismantling of Roe v Wade
column31: the landmark 1973 Supreme Court decision which legalised abortion across the country. In this imagined "post-Roe" United States
column32: some campaigners are making the case that women need to know the facts about how to "self-manage" their own abortions. "This is the next frontier in abortion access
column33: says Erin Matson, co-founder of Reproaction, a pro-choice group that has begun hosting public information sessions on self-managed abortion throughout the US. Everybody has a right to know information about how to safely and effectively end a pregnancy on their own. It's bigger than this political moment." Anti-abortion activists say that even if Roe is overturned
column34: it is unlikely abortion would become illegal across the US
column35: and that it's a dangerous argument for women managing their own care. "All overturning Roe v Wade would do is give the question back to the states and allow the states to legislate the procedure
column36: says Dr Ingrid Skop, an obstetrician-gynecologist in San Antonio, Texas, and a board member of the American Association of Pro-Life OB-GYNs. I think that even if restrictions were put in place so that more women could not access the procedure
column37: that many more women would carry their pregnancies to term and probably many of these women would find that what began as an unintended pregnancy would become a desired pregnancy and a desired child." Though the phrase "self-managed abortion" conjures images of coat hangers and disreputable
column39: campaigners say that is not the world we live in anymore
column40: in large part thanks to the development of abortion with pills
column41: which can be used with about 95% effectiveness until 10 weeks into a pregnancy. "A third of all abortions now
column42: you go to the clinic and get pills and go home and do the abortion
column43: says Dr Beverly Winikoff, founder and president of Gynuity Health Project. Doing an abortion now means swallowing a pill." Such was the case for Kate
column44: who quickly found online pharmacies who could ship her mifepristone and misoprostol from India for half the cost. However
column45: she didn't like the look of the websites or trust that the medication would be genuine. That's when she came across a new site called Aid Access
column46: which quietly came online earlier this spring. The reproductive rights advocates behind websites like Women Help Women
column47: Safe2Choose and Women on Web have been sending abortion pills by mail to countries where abortion is illegal or severely restricted for over a decade. One study found that of 1
column48: 000 Irish women who received pills by mail using the Women on Web service
column49: 95% ended their pregnancies successfully. But until very recently
column50: none of these services would ship to the US - a wealthy
column51: first-world country where abortion is legal
column52: and the anti-abortion movement is politically powerful and litigious. That changed this spring
column54: the Dutch physician behind Women on Web
column55: founded Aid Access. She publicly announced its existence earlier this month
column56: though she estimates she's already sent 600 mifepristone-misoprostol kits to the US since April. Dr Gomperts says that after reading email pleas for help from all over the US and watching how many restrictions states have placed on abortion services over the last 10 years
column57: she decided something had to be done. "It is especially the really poor women who are affected by obstacles that have been put in place in the last years
column58: she says. The need is growing and it's super desperate." When Kate got to Aid Access
column59: she filled out a short survey that asked about the length of her pregnancy
column60: her medical history and her reasons for needing help. She was approved
column61: paid a $95 fee (women too poor to pay can still receive the medication) and gave Aid Access her address. Dr Gomperts wrote Kate the prescription from her private practice in Europe. After the little brown box arrived in the mail (from a pharmacy in India that Dr Gomperts declines to name)
column62: Kate took the medication as instructed
column63: and says that after a sleepless night of painful cramps
column65: she began to bleed. By morning
column66: it was over. "I felt a real sense of relief two days later
column67: she says. I'd been so miserable for what seemed like forever." Aid Access is just the newest way American women can get their hands directly on medication without going through a doctor. Online pharmacies - many located in India - will sell the drugs without a prescription (one research group bought 22 such products online and received 20
column68: and although some of the blister packs were damaged
column69: 72% contained enough of the drug to be effective). Misoprostol - which is less effective than mifepristone but can be used on its own to induce a miscarriage - is sold over the counter in Mexico and has been found for sale at US flea markets near the border. Some activists believe that with accurate information about how to take the medication and when to seek help
column70: abortions can easily be done at home. "We can trust women to make decisions and to manage their own abortions
column71: says Dr Gomperts. Women have a human right to health." Obtaining abortion drugs in the US without a prescription is against the law. The US Food and Drug Administration has placed mifepristone under a Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy
column72: which is a special restriction on distribution for medications that may have serious risks associated with their use. The opioid fentanyl is also under a REMS
column73: for example. Mifepristone can only be distributed in a doctor's office or hospital. In a statement to the BBC
column74: the FDA said it is looking into Aid Access: "The agency takes the allegations related to the sale of mifepristone in the US through online distribution channels very seriously and is evaluating the allegations to assess potential violations of US law." However
column75: many doctors believe that the REMS on mifepristone is unnecessary
column76: and both the American Medical Association
column77: and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists have recommended that the restriction be lifted. "To date
column78: 19 deaths have been reported to the FDA among the more than three million women in the United States who have used [mifepristone]
column79: one working group of doctors wrote in 2017 in the New England Journal of Medicine. Pregnancy-related death... is 14 times higher." Anti-abortion organisations
column81: argue that the medication is not safe enough to be provided over the counter
column82: and that circumventing FDA regulations is even riskier. Women who have an ectopic pregnancy
column83: who have an intrauterine device or who have a history of adrenal health problems are not advised to take mifepristone. Rare complications include sepsis or haemorrhage
column84: which could be life threatening. "Just sort of violating the law and the distribution requirements - there are reasons these things are in place
column85: says Chris Gacek, a senior fellow on regulatory affairs at the Family Research Council. Regardless of your views on abortion
column86: I just don't think this is good medicine." There are other
column87: legal attempts to remove obstacles between patients and medication. Planned Parenthood currently runs telemedicine programmes in 14 states
column88: where a doctor consults with the patient online or via telephone at a clinic that is convenient for her
column89: and if the doctor determines she is eligible for medication abortion
column90: he or she unlocks a drawer containing the pills remotely. Researchers at Gynuity Health Projects are currently running a study that's been filed with the FDA
column91: in which women are directly mailed the drugs after consultation with a physician. However
column92: 19 other states have a ban on abortion drugs being dispensed by telemedicine
column93: and since the medications are not obtainable without a prescription in the US
column94: any pregnant person trying to obtain the pills without a doctor's help is operating in risky legal territory. "I would never encourage anyone to do that
column95: says Tara Kepler, an attorney of counsel at Bryan Cave Leighton Paisner and a telemedicine legal expert. There's no way to get it without a prescription unless you're violating the law." At the same time
column96: Kepler says that she's never heard of legal action being taken against a patient for ordering a prescription online. Activists say that since women will continue trying to self-induce abortion regardless of the legal risks
column97: it is their responsibility to put out helpful
column98: accurate information. "What we know is people were managing their abortions before Roe
column99: and have and will continue to do so without Roe
column100: says Pamela Merritt, co-founder of Reproaction. On a balmy Sunday afternoon, less than 24 hours after the confirmation of Justice Kavanaugh, a small group gathered in the brightly lit basement of an old union hall in St Louis, Missouri. A handwritten sign hung on the door read, Self-Managed Abortion Forum". Attendance was modest - 10 men and women in total - and the bags of crisps and fruit salad sat untouched. Organisers wondered if the event might inspire protest
column102: the sense of urgency in the room was palpable. Several people declined to provide their names
column103: and said that they intentionally did not RSVP to the event on Facebook. "It could be traced back if [abortion] gets criminalised
column105: another said. That could be bad for me." "I'm clergy
column106: added a third. Next to the fruit salad was a stack of fact-sheets which laid out how a regimen of 12 tablets of misoprostol taken four at a time over the course of nine hours can induce an abortion. Misoprostol is typically used within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy and is about 85 percent effective
column107: the card read, next to a cartoon of a woman with four pills under her tongue. Pamela Merritt, one of three panellists at the front of the room, said that to her knowledge, hers is the only group actively promoting information on self-managed abortion. Her co-director Erin Matson acknowledged merely hosting the discussion is radical". Still
column108: they believe the need for these conversations is clear. "The Supreme Court has solidified a 5-4 conservative majority for the foreseeable future
column109: said Merritt. We now must proceed in a way that protects access to care and protects people who are most vulnerable to reproductive oppression." Still
column110: the activists have to be careful. Reproaction's panellists never explain how to obtain the pills. Instead
column111: they refer the audience to links online with more information. "It's actually not that complex
column112: how to use these pills to end a pregnancy. What's complex is how to talk about it in a way that doesn't expose people to legal liability
column113: says Matson. We are not providing advice. We are not coaching people who are self-managing their abortions through the process. We are sharing the World Health Organization's protocol." According to the WHO
column114: "where mifepristone is unavailable" misoprostol - the second drug prescribed for a medication abortion - is the "recommended method of medical abortion". The drug was developed for the treatment of stomach ulcers
column115: but researchers soon discovered it also causes miscarriage. Misoprostol is cheaper and less highly regulated than mifepristone
column116: and there are no tests that would detect it in the blood stream. It is less effective than taking misoprostol together with mifepristone
column117: but in absence of other options
column118: World Health Organization reports say that the regimen is safe and effective at ending pregnancy. In St Louis
column119: one of the panellists was Dr Colleen McNicholas
column120: an obstetrician-gynecologist who - until just the week prior - provided abortion services at clinics in Columbia and Kansas City
column121: Missouri. Newly enforced state regulations revoked her admitting privileges
column122: meaning she can only do abortions at a single clinic located in St Louis. Missouri now joins the ranks of one-clinic states like North Dakota
column123: West Virginia and Kentucky. "If we get to a place where there are states or large portions of the country where there is no access to abortion
column124: I think self-managed abortion will fill at least part of that gap whether we like it or not
column125: says Dr McNicholas. I have both a clinical and moral obligation to help women do the safest thing that they can to achieve the outcome they want. Whether I'm able to actually provide the care is irrelevant." The number of clinics in the Midwest has dropped 22% over the last five years
column126: and the state of Texas alone has shuttered 32 clinics. Thirty-three states have passed laws to limit or restrict patient access to abortion over the past decade. For instance
column128: women must wait 72 hours after their initial doctor visit to get the abortion
column129: a significant obstacle for those who are driving long distances
column130: and may have jobs and need childcare. Merritt says that in places like Missouri
column131: women are already living in the equivalent of a post-Roe world. "For a lot of people abortion access is a right in name only - particularly for people experiencing financial difficulties
column132: she says. At the St Louis discussion, audience members asked questions about legal exposure, and what someone ought to do if she took misoprostol but then needed to go to a hospital with complications. They should say they're pregnant and bleeding
column133: said Dr McNicholas. That's all the information that needs to be given." Self-inducing an abortion with pills carries legal risk. Although no one has ever been prosecuted directly for purchasing abortion drugs online
column134: the act of buying pills has been used as evidence for criminal charges
column135: including murder. The most famous case was Purvi Patel
column136: who was sentenced to 20 years in prison under Indiana's feticide law before her conviction was overturned. Similar cases have played out in Idaho
column137: Virginia and Georgia. In some of these cases
column138: it was a doctor or hospital employee where the woman sought help who contacted police. Dr Skop
column139: the anti-abortion obstetrician-gynecologist in San Antonio
column140: says that if a woman does not tell her doctor that she has tried to self-induce an abortion with misoprostol
column141: she puts her doctor at a disadvantage in her treatment. She adds that she would never turn a woman over to authorities if she found out she'd tried to end her own pregnancy. "I would care for her. I think that most OBGYNs would
column142: she says. At the end of the session in St Louis, some swapped stories about how they were preparing for the end of Roe. Two said they'd been stockpiling doses of Plan B, the so-called morning after pill"
column143: just in case that medication were also discontinued or even criminalised. "We have to protect each other
column144: said one woman. The system is not going to save us." The day after Kate took her pills
column145: her morning sickness was gone and she was able to eat normally for the first time in weeks. The day after that
column146: she was back at work. She says she is no longer pregnant
column147: and confident that she made the right decision. "I'm grateful that I was able to access the medication because I think it's better than the alternative
column148: she says. I didn't understand why it was that expensive
column149: not to mention the drive both ways
column150: and missing work for me. I wouldn't have done it another way." At the same time

column152: which she got free of charge. The delay was extremely stressful and although she knows this is not everyone's experience with the medication

column156: she says. It was pretty traumatic

column164: alone in a hotel room. "I was

column167: Otto says. I was just excited." Kate also says she has no regrets
column168: and the fact that she might be breaking the law didn't scare her or impact her decision to seek out the medication on her own. She's nearly finished with school
column169: and is eager to start a career in massage working specifically with cancer patients. She hopes that by speaking out about her experience
column170: other women in similar situations will do whatever they feel is best for them. "If you end up having to take things in your own hands
column173: she says. I think everybody should have that right." To protect their anonymity
column174: the BBC has changed some names and omitted identifying information. .

When we discovered what happened
column401: we deleted the tweet and issued a corrected one in its place. The image was of hooded participants in a Ku Klux Klan rally in South Carolina
column402: and it was paired with the language
column403: "What's going on this weekend? We've got you covered." That struck many readers as offensive
column404: and we agree. We thought it was worth explaining what happened. When an editor programmed the tweet to publish at 7 a.m.
column405: we didn't know that an automatic scraper from Twitter would pull in the image of the KKK rally. We didn't have a way to preview this
column406: and the result was a tweet that we regret. In our internal content management system
column407: we had chosen a different photo to default with that article
column408: but this selection did not carry over to the image that Twitter automatically pulled in with the link. USA TODAY uses tools to keep readers informed and engaged at all hours of the day. These constantly evolve
column409: and so do we. We're taking another look at our software and practices to make sure something like this doesn't happen again. column2: Facebook shut down another network of 82 accounts
column4: and groups that have been posing as US and UK citizens since 2016. The network
column5: which Facebook says originated in Iran
column8: and other posts about political topics including race relations
column9: the upcoming midterm election in the US
column10: and the recent confirmation hearings for Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh. It also hosted seven events. What distinguishes this latest group
column11: which Facebooks says it discovered a week ago
column12: from the Iranian propaganda network that tech giants shut down this past summer are the striking similarities between its campaign and the one the Russians mounted before the 2016 election. Rather than focusing on the Iranian regime's agenda at home
column13: the new network focused squarely on American and British politics. As it turns out
column14: that may be a more successful strategy: While the network discovered this summer had just around 200
column16: this latest batch had more than one million. "This content appeared consistent with what we’ve seen in other major operations
column17: Facebook's head of cybersecurity policy, Nathaniel Gleicher, said on a call with reporters Friday. It was targeting broad division. It was sowing discord and targeting socially divisive issues." In August
column20: and Google suspended an expansive web of phony social media accounts and websites linked to the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting
column21: a state-owned news network. Those pages and accounts
column22: which were first spotted by the cybersecurity firm FireEye
column23: posed as ordinary citizens as well as journalists and news organizations that advocated for policies explicitly favoring Iran. This latest batch took a different tack. While there was some anti-Saudi and anti-Israeli content sprinkled throughout
column24: the accounts and pages mostly pretended to be American liberals
column25: and they posted divisive content about American politics
column26: according to the Atlantic Council's Digital Forensics Research Lab
column27: which is working with Facebook to dissect the operation. Unlike this summer's batch
column28: Facebook says it has no indication yet that the most recent network is linked to the Iranian government. "This looks like an Iranian operation which learned from earlier Russian ones
column29: says Ben Nimmo, a senior fellow at the DFRLab. According to DFRLab director Graham Brookie, his team had less than 24 hours notice to piece through the content. They published some preliminary findings shortly after Facebook's announcement. The most staggering difference between the two Iranian campaigns is how much engagement the most recent one received on Facebook and Instagram. According to DFRLab, one page, titled I Need Justice Now
column30: amassed more than 13 million video views on Facebook. Another, titled No Racism No War
column31: received more than 10 million views. DFRLab's researchers note, however, that some of the engagement on these posts appears to have been artificially amplified because it so far exceeds the number of followers the accounts had. Gleicher says Facebook did find links between this network and the one it had shut down in August. He says Facebook researchers manually combed the accounts for signs of inauthentic coordinated activity. Despite those links, however, it seems the accounts taken down Friday were far more recent. Their earliest post was in June 2016, but Gleicher says “the majority of the activity is over the last year.” The Iranian pages homed in on national news events in the US like the Kavanaugh hearings. One cartoon posted to the page No Racism No War" showed Kavanaugh griping about his life being “destroyed by unproven allegations without a trial.” Behind him
column33: sitting with other victims of police brutality
column36: bro.” The pages also shared articles from mainstream news sources. In September
column37: the "I Need Justice" page shared a Daily Beast article with the headline “Stormy Daniels: Trump’s Penis Looks like Toad from Mario Kart.” Like the Russian pages
column38: this set shared highly divisive content that primarily skewed negative. "Zionism is terrorism
column39: read one post on the Instagram account @know_the_realities. But there were a few odd exceptions. DFRLab released a slew of posts from the No Racism No War" page that just encouraged Americans to vote. This is not the first parallel researchers have found between the Iranian and Russian operations. In August
column41: director of the Digital Forensics Initiative at the Tow Center for Digital Journalism
column42: discovered another unusual link: On a page called "Music Extension
column43: which promotes a Chrome extension connected to Russia's Internet Research Agency, Facebook's Related Pages section recommended The British Left
column44: one of the phony Iranian pages taken down this summer. The Music Extension" page was still live on Friday. "There are either network-based connections or advertising-based connections that somehow link those pages
column45: Albright says. It wouldn't randomly suggest a British propaganda page on a music page. They have nothing in common." Albright took a screenshot of the related page recommendation and shared it on Twitter in August. Since then
column46: Facebook has not answered WIRED's repeated requests for comment on why that referral might have occurred. But the company says it has not found any connections between the Iranian and Russian accounts. Whether that recommendation is an algorithmic quirk or some sign of a deeper link between the Russian and Iranian campaigns is unclear. Given the diplomatic ties between the two nations and the mounting signs that they're following the same playbook
column47: knowing the answer to that question seems more critical than ever. Former Chief of Disguise for the CIA
column49: explains how disguises are used in the CIA
column50: and what aspects to the deception make for an effective disguise. column3: has referred attorney Michael Avenatti and his client Julie Swetnick to the Justice Department for criminal investigation related to accusations they made against Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh during his confirmation process. (Tom Williams/CQ Roll Call file photo) Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley is referring attorney Michael Avenatti and his client Julie Swetnick to the Justice Department for criminal investigation related to their accusations against Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh during his confirmation process. Swetnick was among the women who came forward to accuse Kavanaugh of sexual assault. Specifically
column4: she said she observed Kavanaugh and his friends drinking to excess at parties in high school and lining up outside bedrooms to gang rape females. Grassley sent a letter Thursday to Attorney General Jeff Sessions and the FBI Director Christopher Wray asking they investigate Avenatti and Swetnik for three potential criminal violations: conspiracy
column5: false statements and obstruction of Congress. In the 12-page letter
column6: Grassley outlines the allegations Avenatti and Swetnik made and times in which there were contradictions in their story that led him to question the truth of their statements. He included 17 pages worth of attachments to back up his concerns. Grassley said in a statement that he appreciates when “well-meaning” citizens come forward with information relevant to the committee’s work and takes allegations of sexual misconduct seriously. ICYMI: Massive
column7: Loud and Passionate Anti-Kavanaugh Protest Takes Over Hart Building “But in the heat of partisan moments
column8: some do try to knowingly mislead the committee
column9: ” he said. “That’s unfair to my colleagues
column10: the nominees and others providing information who are seeking the truth. It stifles our ability to work on legitimate lines of inquiry. It also wastes time and resources for destructive reasons.” Grassley said that he doesn’t make a referral of this nature lightly but he can’t brush aside potential violations of the law. “Ignoring this behavior will just invite more of it in the future
column11: ” he said. Avenatti said in a tweet that he welcomes the investigation because it can shed light on “Kavanaugh’s lies and conduct.” It is ironic that Senator Grassley now is interested in investigations. He didn’t care when it came to putting a man on the SCOTUS for life. We welcome the investigation as now we can finally get to the bottom of Judge Kavanaugh’s lies and conduct. Let the truth be known.  Get breaking news alerts and more from Roll Call on your iPhone or your Android. column60: I Enter the No-Predictions Zone OPINION — To watch the World Series or the baseball playoffs is an invitation to enter the realm of the irrelevant statistic. When the Red Sox pushed across their first run in the first inning Monday night
column61: a Fox announcer burbled that Boston also scored in the first inning of the opening game when they won the Series in 2004
column63: no players from 2004 and 2007 are on the active Red Sox roster — and scoring in the second or fifth inning can also be an effective way of winning a ballgame. Highlighted on the screen every night are the postseason stats of the players
column66: played just 11 games to advance to the World Series. Virtually invisible during the telecasts are what the players accomplished during the full 162-game season
column67: even though these numbers have infinitely more predictive value. Those of us who closely follow politics can easily feel superior to the statistical naïfs in the World Series broadcast booth. But often we fall into a similar trap — the arrogant belief that the future is knowable if you crunch enough numbers. The 2018 midterms have brought a new level of sophistication to political analysis. The New York Times in conjunction with Siena College has completed more than 60 congressional polls with the real-time results flashed on the computer screen with each call. Polling analysts like Nate Silver at FiveThirtyEight have honed their predictive models. And traditional race-by-race handicappers like Nathan Gonzales
column68: Charlie Cook and Larry Sabato’s Crystal Ball do an exemplary job on the granular level. Yet
column69: even after hearing cautionary words about polling and polling analysis
column70: we tend to overreact to every statistical gyration. A Rutgers-Eagleton Senate poll from New Jersey
column72: shows scandal-scarred Democratic incumbent Robert Menendez up by just 5 points in a state that Hillary Clinton carried by 14 points. Is the race tightening? Could Democrats blow a seemingly safe seat? Or is the poll just a margin-of-error quirk? Multiply this reaction by nearly 500 contested races for Congress and governor
column73: and you have a rough sense of the stress levels on both sides less than 300 hours before the polls open on Election Day. The truth is that all the polling in the world cannot prepare you for a midterm election with this broad a terrain. And there are many hard-fought House races
column75: where there have only been a handful of reputable polls. Sure
column76: broad questions like the generic ballot (“Do you prefer a Congress controlled by the Democrats or the Republicans?”) can offer national clues. But is the Democrats’ current 8-point average edge on this question enough to comfortably overcome the GOP-leaning effects of incumbency and gerrymandering in the House? A recent Washington Post-Schar School poll of 69 hotly contested House districts found the two parties effectively tied. But is this good news for the Republicans because they are holding their own in battleground races? Or is this a formula for a Democratic sweep since more than 90 percent of the districts surveyed are currently GOP held? Knotty questions like these can make political pundits sound like medieval theologians debating how many angels can dance on the head of a pin. At a certain level there are no hard truths about the 2018 elections yet — only personal tendencies towards optimism or pessimism. After enduring Election Night 2016
column77: many Democrats are like battered children brooding that once again victory (this time
column78: winning the House) will be snatched from their grasp. Similarly
column79: there are Republicans who believe that Donald Trump will help them defy the polls
column80: while other GOP strategists privately worry that a president with no impulse control is leading them to political doom. For all the twitchiness of the political class
column81: it is also worth remembering that the prevalence of early voting in many states cuts into the ability of a single late-breaking event to reshape the midterms. Already
column83: we are approaching the point when it is too late to effectively drop opposition research. Watch: Initial Early Voting Data Appears to Favor GOP in Several Key States Sometimes politics is simply perverse. This is not a reference to the Trump triumph in 2016
column84: but rather to an earlier midterm election that should serve as a cautionary tale for all those eager to make glib predictions. In 1986
column85: the Democrats won seven Senate seats by a collective margin of 98
column87: 000 votes were the difference between a 55-45 Democratic Senate and one that was controlled by the GOP. As House Speaker Tip O’Neill said triumphantly after the election
column93: “You only go around once in life — go for all the gusto you can.” In elections
column95: you only go around once. So it doesn’t matter that in some alternate universe Hillary Clinton is president and the Republicans held the Senate for Ronald Reagan in 1986. Whatever happens on Nov. 6 will seem foreordained by the gods
column97: it will be just one of dozens of equally plausible outcomes. What four decades covering politics has taught me more than anything is humility. Neither I nor anyone practicing punditry on cable TV has the gift of prophesy. But
column99: I would say that the election comes down to how voters sort out the three dominant fundamentals: A booming economy
column100: albeit with a suddenly shaky stock market. A president who violates every rule of decency with his incessant fearmongering and vicious attacks. And a Democratic Party able to aggressively compete across a broad swatch of GOP-held House districts while grappling with a Senate map wildly tilted toward the Republicans. Beyond that
column101: I will be a traitor to the pundit class as I dispense with glib predictions. Instead
column102: I will bow toward the unknowable as I breathlessly wait until the returns come in on Election Night. Walter Shapiro

column158: One Vote. Is It That Complicated? OPINION — I admit that voting is and has always been a celebratory ritual for me

column165: leading voter registration drives in the country he protected. Mine is not a controversial stand — in fact

When Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts in 2013 wrote the majority opinion gutting key provisions of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 — those that compelled certain states to “preclear” any changes in their voting rules — he insisted that so much had changed in the country that those rules were no longer needed. “The Act imposes current burdens and must be justified by current needs.” Racism is dead
column170: he seemed to declare. I would not call Associate Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s dissent cynical. It was realistic. As she wrote: “As the record for the 2006 reauthorization makes abundantly clear
column171: second-generation barriers to minority voting rights have emerged in the covered jurisdictions as attempted substitutes for the first-generation barriers that originally triggered preclearance in those jurisdictions.” What Year Is It? column270: included a provision that prohibited insurance companies from denying coverage for people with pre-existing conditions. However
column271: it also provided states an avenue to waive certain regulations
column272: which could have allowed insurance companies to charge people with pre-existing conditions more for coverage
column273: potentially rendering health care unaffordable. McSally voted for the GOP bill
column274: and reportedly told her Republican colleagues the day of the vote to get this “f---ing thing” done. McSally’s Democratic opponent
column276: has made health care central to her campaign. The two lawmakers are competing in an open seat race to replace retiring GOP Sen. Jeff Flake. Sinema accused McSally in a tweet Wednesday of lying about her record in response to a new McSally television ad where she said she has worked to force insurance companies to protect people with pre-existing conditions. “Here’s the truth: I voted to protect coverage for the 2.8 million Arizonans with pre-existing conditions
column277: ” Sinema tweeted. “Martha voted to take it away.” Inside Elections with Nathan L. Gonzales rates the race a Toss-Up. Politics NARAL Launches Final Push to Fire Up Abortion Rights Voters With voters already casting ballots in states that allow early voting
column278: outside advocacy groups are not just trying to reach potential new voters — they’re working to make sure their most ardent supporters actually show up. That is certainly the case with NARAL
column279: which is announcing a final push to make sure that the abortion rights group’s supporters get out to vote in 2018. The organization is launching a new $750
column280: 000 campaign that will feature direct mail and digital advertising geared toward supporters in 17 key races as the campaign cycle nears its end. According to a listing provided to Roll Call ahead of formal release

column284: Nevada and Wisconsin. According to a summary of the plan for the final weeks
column285: which was provided first to Roll Call
column286: the House races involved include key seats in Arizona
column291: Texas and Virginia. NARAL is also targeting the governor’s races in Iowa
column292: New Mexico and Nevada. NARAL is trying to make sure that the group’s core supporters

column294: actually make it to the polls (either through early voting where it’s possible or on Election Day). “Based on the energy we are seeing from voters across the country

column296: ” said NARAL Pro-Choice America President Ilyse Hogue. “The threat to Roe v. Wade is real and on the horizon.” “Women are fired up and ready to elect candidates in their communities who support us and our families. Our job is to reach as many of them as possible in the next two weeks
column297: ” Hogue said. In addition to a national umbrella digital ad

Politics GOP Ads Target Young Female Voters on Violence Against Women Act An outside group dedicated to electing Republican women is launching digital ads urging three lawmakers to support reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act
column309: which is set to expire in December. The digital ads
column311: target Reps. Mimi Walters of California and Barbara Comstock of Virginia — both facing tough re-elections — and Rep. Martha McSally of Arizona
column312: who’s running for Senate. All three are being challenged by Democratic women. In a year that’s seen high enthusiasm among female voters for Democratic candidates
column314: these issue ads try to highlight GOP lawmakers’ advocacy for women. Republicans are at risk of seeing the number of women in their House conference decline next year. Running on Facebook
column319: the ads are targeted to younger women
column321: and are backed by a six-figure digital buy across the three states. The ads are part of the MyRoar campaign
column322: which is paid for by Winning for Women. The group’s PAC has endorsed all three women
column323: who are also identified as “Lionesses” on the MyRoar website. One version of the ad begins by explaining the Violence Against Women Act. “What if there was a law that provided defense for victims of sexual assault?” the narrator asks. “Well that law expires in just months
column324: ” the narrator continues. “But what if I told you you could help the efforts of women like Congresswoman Barbara Comstock to keep it alive when Congress returns?” “What if I told you that you could be heard?” the narrator says
column325: as the face of a young woman appears on screen. Another version of the ad opens with statistics about rape and sexual assault and the percentage of the offenders who see jail time. Things would be “a lot worse” without the Violence Against Women Act
column326: the narrator says. “Congresswoman Mimi Walters has been working hard for women. Learn how to help Mimi keep working to pass a bigger
column327: better Violence Against Women Act when Congress returns
column328: ” the narrator says. The Violence Against Women Act was supposed to expire on Sept. 30
column329: but it was extended under a stopgap spending bill in September. Led by Texas Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee
column330: Democrats have introduced legislation to reauthorize the law with updates
column331: including a provision that would prohibit those under protective order from possessing firearms. No Republicans have signed on to the Democratic proposal. Flashback: Democrats Hope to Extend Violence Against Women Act GOP Reps. Elise Stefanik and John J. Faso of New York and Rep. Brian Fitzpatrick of Pennsylvania introduced their own six-month reauthorization legislation in September. Walters is listed as a co-sponsor on that measure. Comstock and McSally are not. Forty-six Republicans sent a letter to Speaker Paul D. Ryan and Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy last month asking for urgent action to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act before its Sept. 30 expiration. Comstock and Walters signed on to that letter. McSally did not. “In Congress
column332: all three of these women have a strong track record of supporting legislation that promotes and empowers women. Each is a warrior. And we look forward to their continued commitment to the Violence Against Women Act and to victims of violence and sexual assault across the country
column333: ” Winning For Women Executive Director Rebecca Schuller said in a statement. Comstock is running for a third term in Virginia's 10th District against Democratic state Sen. Jennifer Wexton. Jon Kyl was appointed to McCain’s seat
column339: but he has said he plans to step down at the end of the year. “At the end of the day
column340: I think we’re going to make a determination based on: Can we win? And can we make a difference for Arizona?” Gallego said in an interview here at a local coffee shop Tuesday morning. “And that’s it. I’m not really worried about a primary.” The two-term congressman from the 7th District was confident he could defeat Grant Woods
column341: McCain’s former chief of staff and onetime state attorney general. Woods has said he is considering switching parties to run as a Democrat or independent. “Grant Woods cannot win a Democratic primary in Arizona. So he can make his own determination
column342: and I will just make my own in my own time

Inside Elections with Nathan L. Gonzales rates the race a Toss-up. “It’s difficult winning statewide here. And luckily you have a great example in how Sinema is being competitive about it

column366: Stupid House Midterm Outlook: Look for a Democratic Flip Pelosi Suggests 2020 Outcome Will Help Her Decide Whether to Stay in Congress What Will Trump Do About Khashoggi? ‘Leave It Up to Congress’ Politics Sandra Day O’Connor Leaves a Political and Judicial Legacy Sandra Day O’Connor’s announcement Tuesday that she was stepping away from public life brings into stark relief the legacy of not just the first woman to serve on the Supreme Court
column367: but that of a fading model for what a justice could be: a politician actively engaged in the civic arena. Citing a dementia diagnosis that would most likely progress to Alzheimer’s disease
column368: the 88-year-old said she was “no longer able to participate in public life
column369: ” something that defined her career. In making her announcement
column370: O’Connor reminded the nation that the high court
column371: on which she served from 1981 to 2006
column372: was bookended by public service as not only a judge but as an accomplished state legislator and as a senior judge and elder stateswoman on political engagement through her founding of the group iCivics. “Not long after I retired from the Supreme Court twelve years ago
column373: I made a commitment to myself
column375: and my country that I would use whatever years I had left to advance civic learning and engagement. I feel so strongly about the topic because I’ve seen first-hand how vital it is for all citizens to understand our Constitution and unique system of government
column376: and participate actively in their communities
column377: ” she wrote in the letter announcing her decision on Tuesday. The confirmation fight of the newest justice
column379: was a bitter partisan fight that partially centered on whether
column380: given his background in the George W. Bush White House and his work for Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr during the impeachment of President Bill Clinton
column381: he could be an impartial jurist given his history in politics. But O’Connor showed that a political career need not necessarily taint a jurist’s. In 1969
column382: she was appointed to an Arizona state Senate seat
column383: then won election to it outright in 1970. She went on to become majority leader
column384: another first for a woman in the Legislature
column385: before opting to run for election to a local judgeship. That set her along the path that would lead to President Ronald Reagan making her the first woman on the high court. After her retirement from Supreme Court
column386: she continued to hear cases as many retired justices do
column388: all the while starting iCivics and taking care of her husband John Jay O’Connor III
column389: who died in 2009 of Alzheimer’s disease. Chief Justice John Roberts had that civic legacy in mind in his response to the news. “I was saddened to learn that Justice Sandra Day O’Connor
column391: faces the challenge of dementia. But I was not at all surprised that she used the occasion of sharing that fact to think of our country first
column392: and to urge an increased commitment to civics education
column393: a cause to which she devoted so much of her time and indomitable energy
column394: ” Roberts wrote in a statement released by the Supreme Court. It is fitting that O’Connor’s announcement comes the same day the legacy institution of another Arizona icon
column396: announced an initiative to encourage civic participation
column397: voting and respect for human rights. The McCain Institute’s “Mavericks Needed” campaign will run an ad through Election Day and then start a second campaign to last through 2020. “Now more than ever
column398: America needs a new generation of Mavericks to stand up
column401: get in the area and vote on November 6th
column403: said in a statement. Cindy McCain was elected chairwoman of the McCain Institute last week. The two Arizonans
column404: both of whom came to Washington in the early 1980s

Policy Rob Portman’s Report on Trump Trade Policy to Feature Mixed Results A key Republican senator sees positive signs in the Trump administration’s trade discussions with Canada and Mexico
column414: but he still has plenty of criticism for the White House
column415: too. In a major trade policy speech at the Heritage Foundation on Tuesday morning
column416: Sen. Rob Portman is planning to focus on the effects of the Trump trade agenda on the auto industry
column417: a key business in his manufacturing-heavy home state of Ohio. “I’m still reviewing the details of the updated NAFTA agreement
column418: now called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement
column419: but I am encouraged by what I’ve seen so far
column422: is expected to say. “One of the most substantial changes to NAFTA is the rules of origin for automobiles. In the time since NAFTA was ratified 24 years ago
column423: the United States has lost about 350
column426: 000.” Portman’s indications of support of that framework is in contrast with his view of what the Commerce Department has done with using Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act to impose tariffs
column428: using a nebulous “national security” justification. In his remarks
column429: Portman is expected to speak to the proposal
column430: which has been stalled in the Senate
column431: to rework the trade law to restrict it to true national security implications. “The administration has used Section 232 to impose a new 25 percent tariff on steel and 10 percent tariff on aluminum imports worldwide
column432: ” the Ohio senator is expected to say. “For certain countries and certain products
column433: I believe there is a national security issue with steel — including electrical steel
column434: which is critical to the grid. But broadly imposing tariffs on our allies risks them retaliating by putting tariffs on our products.” “Simply put
column435: auto and auto part imports are not a national security threat
column436: and as I’ve been saying for months
column437: these tariffs are a bad idea
column438: ” reads a copy of Portman’s prepared speech
column439: which was obtained by Roll Call. Portman will outline views more favorable to Trump and the harder line of his administration when it comes to trade with China
column440: citing Chinese policies such as requirements for joint ventures for U.S. automakers to do business in the communist country. The speech is expected to include a degree of support for the tariff announcements as part of negotiations with China. “While I do have concerns about some of the collateral damage these tariffs can do to folks trying to make products in America
column441: I think this assertiveness on China is needed
column442: ” Portman is scheduled to say. “Republican and Democrat administrations alike have tried to get China’s attention on the trade issue and failed. China has been violating and circumventing our trade laws for decades. I think the Trump administration now has China’s attention
column443: and I applaud the president for taking a tough stand.” But Portman is also expected to say that he does not view shortcuts like the purchase of additional soybeans from American producers by China as a solution to the trade issues between the two countries. “Instead
column444: the United States should push for structural changes to the Chinese economy to reduce the ways Beijing distorts the economy in its favor and tilts the playing field away from American workers
column445: ” Portman is scheduled to tell the Heritage audience. Watch: One Month Out

column1: 5.0-split-https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/battleground-house-districts-remain-close-in-new-poll/2018/10/22/e6c77a32-d63e-11e8-aeb7-ddcad4a0a54e_story.html?utm_term=.11cdb96b36eb-split-The contest for control of the House remains close and hard fought
column2: according to a new Washington Post-Schar School poll of the most-contested districts in the country
column3: with Democrats holding a statistically insignificant lead over Republicans. The latest survey shows only a marginal change in the race during October
column4: with 50 percent currently supporting the Democratic candidate in their district and 47 percent backing the Republican. Candidates from the two parties collectively are running almost even in 48 contested congressional districts won by President Trump in 2016
column5: while Democrats hold the advantage in 21 competitive districts won by Hillary Clinton. The Democrats’ lead in those Clinton districts has narrowed a bit since the beginning of the month. The overwhelming majority of the districts surveyed — 63 of the 69 — are currently represented by a Republican in the House. Collectively these battleground districts voted strongly for Republicans in the 2016 election. The fact that the margins today are where they are illustrates the degree to which the GOP majority is at risk but also the fact that many individual races are likely to be close. Democrats need to gain a net of 23 seats to take control of the chamber. [Read the full poll results ] Overall
column6: likely voters in these districts give the two major parties mixed-to-negative marks. Democrats are rated favorably by 48 percent and unfavorably by 52 percent. For Republicans
column7: it’s 47 percent positive and 53 percent negative. Most voters have a favorable view of one party and a negative view of the other party
column8: but 10 percent say they dislike both parties. Voters in that group say they prefer the Democratic candidates in their districts by 15 points. Four years ago
column9: when the GOP made gains in the midterms
column10: voters who rated both parties negatively at this point in the election said they preferred Republican candidates for the House by 17 points. The battle over the confirmation of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court has energized voters on both sides
column11: according to the poll. About 6 in 10 likely voters in each party say they are more motivated to vote on Nov. 6 as a result of the clash
column12: which included allegations of sexual misconduct against Kavanaugh that drove fierce denials from him and other Republicans. Among independents with no partisan leanings
column13: about half say it has motivated them to vote. [How the poll was conducted ] The Kavanaugh hearings split the country
column14: with many Americans saying they believed Christine Blasey Ford
column15: who accused the judge of sexually assaulting her when both were in high school in the Washington suburbs
column16: and many others saying they believed Kavanaugh’s denials that he was innocent of the charge. The new survey finds that a majority of battleground district voters (57 percent) say they are concerned that men they are close to might be unfairly accused of sexual assault. But a far larger majority (78 percent) say they are concerned that women in this country are not believed when they report that they were sexually assaulted. Overall
column18: Americans say the bigger problem is that women who report that they were sexually assaulted are not believed. On a related question
column19: a 54 percent majority of likely voters say that men who commit sexual assault face serious consequences less than half the time. More women than men hold those perceptions
column20: 60 percent to 49 percent. Eight in 10 Democrats and just over 3 in 10 Republicans say men who commit such acts don’t face serious consequences most of the time. The Kavanaugh confirmation turned into a supercharged partisan fight
column21: and the findings in the new Post-Schar School survey bear that out in responses to the questions about men and women. Republicans are far more likely than Democrats to say they are concerned that men can be accused unfairly of sexual assault
column22: 76 percent vs. 34 percent. That argument was put forth by Trump and other Republicans as Kavanaugh fought to save his nomination. Conversely
column23: Democrats are much more likely to say they worry that women who report sexual assaults are not believed
column24: with 98 percent of Democrats saying they are concerned about this compared with 63 percent of Republicans. Democratic leaders had made that argument in defense of Ford
column25: who they said should be believed although she only began to share news of her alleged assault decades after it happened. Among political independents
column26: 59 percent say they are concerned that men close to them might be unfairly accused of sexual assault
column27: while 74 percent are concerned about women not being believed when they report assault. On both questions
column28: independents are somewhat closer to Republicans than Democrats. On the question of which of the two is the bigger problem
column29: 92 percent of Democrats say it is that women are not believed
column30: while 69 percent of Republicans say their concern is unfair accusations against men. Among independents
column31: 55 percent say the bigger problem is women not being believed. The survey by The Post and George Mason University’s Schar School of Policy and Government was conducted in 69 congressional districts rated as competitive in late August by the team at the Cook Political Report and Post political staff. Surveys identified the major-party candidates by name in each district. This survey was a follow-up with voters who were initially interviewed in late September and early October. The survey
column32: which was in the field Oct. 15-21
column33: did not attempt to measure the state of races for the Senate. Results among the sample of 1
column34: 269 likely voters have an error margin of plus or minus three percentage points. Overall
column35: there was little movement between the two polls
column36: with 93 percent of those surveyed supporting the same candidate as in the first round. Of those who changed
column37: 2 percent switched from Democrat to Republican and 2 percent switched from Republican to Democrat. The remainder switched from having no opinion to one of the parties. If anything
column38: partisan attitudes hardened during the month. Today
column39: 95 percent of Democrats say they support the Democratic candidate in their district
column40: and 90 percent of Republicans support the GOP contender. In the first survey
column41: 93 percent of Democrats and 87 percent of Republicans supported their party’s candidate. To the degree that Democrats have any edge in these districts
column42: it is because of support from women
column43: as was the case in the previous poll. Among likely voters
column44: men favor Republican candidates by 51 to 46 percent
column45: while women back Democrats by 55 to 42 percent. Nonwhite voters back Democrats 2 to 1
column46: while white voters back Republicans by a statistically insignificant three points
column48: small majorities of men with college degrees and without degrees and women without college degrees say they support Republican candidates. But white women with college degrees support Democratic candidates by a 23-point margin. Nearly twice as many likely voters who support Republican candidates say their vote is more in favor of the GOP candidate than against the Democrat
column49: 51 percent to 27 percent. Voters who support Democrats also tend to say they are motivated more by support for the party’s candidate than opposition to the Republican
column50: albeit by a smaller 45 percent to 29 percent margin. Interest in the election remains high
column51: with a Washington Post-ABC News poll earlier this month finding 77 percent of registered voters saying they are certain to vote or have voted early
column52: up from 65 percent in October 2014. Some people who say they will definitely vote end up not doing so
column53: but in states that allow early voting
column54: there has been an early surge of interest that could signal higher-than-normal turnout for midterm elections. Emily Guskin contributed to this report.
